Title:
The polyphyletic origin of endoparasitism in the cyclostome
lineages of Braconidae (Hymenoptera).
Abstract:
The evolution of endoparasitism in braconid wasps is
demonstrably polyphyletic, not only within the family as a whole but
even within the rogadine/exothecine assemblage of genera. A cladistic
analysis of rogadine and exothecine genera, coupled with an optimization
approach to estimating ancestral character states, is used to analyze
the evolution of various aspects of endoparasitism within this
assemblage. At least two independent origins of endoparasitism are
hypothesized - one in the Rogadini and the other in an assmeblage
including the Gnaptodontinae, Opiinae and Alysiinae. Phylogenetic
analyes and hypotheses can be useful not only in interpreting
evolutionary trends, but in guiding and providing insights into more
general comparative behavioural and physiological studies of
parasitism.
